--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
<snip>
> > yeast, algae, etc.  Even those are much more
> > complicated than our models, but they are closer,
> > since we don't have sexual reproduction, nor many
> > other genetic & developmental phenomena found in
> > nature.  So I think we should model our work after
> > the
> > simplest organisms that we know something about.
> 
> Well, but NEAT does employ sexual reproduction,
> albeit
> a very simplified representation of it, which is
> obviously a more complicated mode of reproduction
> than
> asexual reproduction.
> 
> If we only used the simplest models from nature,
> then
> we would be potentially excluding some of the most
> effective evolutionary features.
> 
> You're right that we should keep in mind that our
> models are nowhere near the complexity of biological
> ones, and so analogy with real-world organisms
> sometimes breaks down.  But if we're modeling sexual
> reproduction, obviously we need to draw analogies
> from
> organisms that actually reproduce that way.

Perhaps we don't mean the same thing by the term
"sexual reproduction".  I was referring to the
phenomenon of gender, whereby the population of one
species is divided into two groups, and mating can
only be with an individual from the other group. 
Also, each individual carries a pair of homologous
chromosomes, one of which came from the father and the
other from the mother.  The phenotype depends on both
chromosomes in a complicated way. (And of course there
are multiple pairs of chromosomes in most species.)

NEAT doesn't model any of that, or did I miss that in
my reading?  That's why I suggested bacteria, yeast
and algae as our natural models.

=====
Mitchell Timin
